korean.description: The letters in this category have strokes that are based off of traditional calligraphy.

english.description: The letters in this category have thicker strokes and are based off of traditional calligraphy.

korean.description: The strokes are thinner and the serifs are more refined. Overall there is less direct influence from the calligraphic brush strokes.

english.description: The contrast between thick and thin strokes is heightened and the serifs are more refined because of advances in printing technology.

korean.description: Heightened contrast between thick and thin strokes are a required feature, however the contrast does not have to be an extreme amount.

english.description: Extreme contrast between the thick and thin strokes become possible due to more advances in technology, usually featured with thin lined serifs.

korean.description: The serifs are more square-like. There is little to no contrast between the thicks and thins of the strokes.

english.description: The serifs are more square-like. There is little to no contrast between the thicks and thins of the strokes.

korean.description: The stroke shape and contrast is influenced by the original brush strokes from the written letters. There are no serifs.

english.description: The stroke shape and contrast is influenced by calligraphy and it’s serifed predecessors. However, there are no serifs.

korean.description: The strokes have no contrast between the thicks and thins. The letter shapes are highly influenced by perfectly geometric lines and circles.

english.description: The strokes have little to no contrast between thicks and thins. The letter shapes are highly influenced by perfectly geometric lines and circles.

korean.description: There is no contrast between the thick and thin strokes. The letters are more regulated when contrasted with one another.

english.description: The stroke's thicks and thins have very slight contrast and the letters are more regulated when contrasted with one another.
